SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including words that affect meaning and tone.
Content: What is the meaning of “lunged” in this sentence from paragraph 7?
:ibox:“The dogs’ ears stood erect as the team lunged forward.”

A.Choice: jumped

B.Choice: served

C.Choice: forced

D.Choice: stepped

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does the word “jolted” mean in paragraph 8?

A.Choice: circled

B.Choice: bounced

C.Choice: reached

D.Choice: stopped

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: Which quote from the text describes the setting?

A.Choice: “Her brown eyes peeked out of the fur-lined hood which outlined her round, full face.”

B.Choice: “She held tightly to the sides of the sled with her oversized gloves.”

C.Choice: “Libby reached out toward the pine trees and grabbed one of the now-covered branches.”

D.Choice: “She reached down for the metal anchor and pushed it over the edge of the sled.”

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: Which event changes how Libby feels about the sled ride?

A.Choice: Snow gets stirred up all around them.

B.Choice: Her dad is bumped off the sled in the last turn.

C.Choice: The wind throws snow in her face.

D.Choice: The dogs run through the woods faster than ever.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why does Libby snap off a pine twig and swing it between Timber and Tucker?

A.Choice: to make the dogs start walking

B.Choice: to make the dogs go into the woods

C.Choice: to make the dogs stop running

D.Choice: to make the dogs go faster

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: What does the action that Libby took to save the team show about her character?

A.Choice: She is brave.

B.Choice: She is frightened.

C.Choice: She is excited.

D.Choice: She is comfortable.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which statement summarizes the text?

A.Choice: Libby and her dad take turns driving the sled.

B.Choice: Libby learns how to control a sled pulled by dogs.

C.Choice: Libby takes control of the sled when her dad falls off.

D.Choice: Libby learns how to lead the sled through the trees.Libby learns how to lead the sled through the trees.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why is Libby’s father proud of her at the end of the text?

A.Choice: Libby wanted to go on a sled ride.

B.Choice: Libby saved the dogs and the sled.

C.Choice: Libby commanded the dogs to go faster.

D.Choice: Libby turned the team around to look for her dad.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: According to the selection, why was Amelia unhappy with her flight on Friendship?

A.Choice: Her landing was not smooth.

B.Choice: She did not fly across the Pacific.

C.Choice: Her plane disappeared.

D.Choice: She was not the pilot.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: What evidence from the selection shows how Amelia supported other women who wanted to become pilots?

A.Choice: Amelia wrote books and gave talks about flying.

B.Choice: Amelia accepted a job at Purdue University.

C.Choice: Amelia gave speeches with Franklin D. Roosevelt.

D.Choice: Amelia started the group The Ninety-Nines in 1929.

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: In paragraph 8, what is the meaning of the word originally?

A.Choice: in the middle

B.Choice: at the end

C.Choice: in the beginning

D.Choice: at a slow rate

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Whose wife made speeches with Amelia Earhart?

A.Choice: Franklin Roosevelt’s

B.Choice: Wilmer Stultz’s

C.Choice: Edwin Elliot’s

D.Choice: Fred Noonan’s

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: In paragraph 10, what is the meaning of the word impressed?

A.Choice: admired

B.Choice: disliked

C.Choice: forced

D.Choice: imitated

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: Why was Amelia Earhart asked to be a career counselor?

A.Choice: She planned a flight around the world.

B.Choice: She encouraged women’s rights.

C.Choice: She knew the president and his wife.

D.Choice: She advised women students at Purdue.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: In paragraph 12, what is another name for “navigator”?

A.Choice: fighter

B.Choice: target

C.Choice: customer

D.Choice: guide

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: What is the main idea of the selection?

A.Choice: Amelia Earhart and Eleanor Roosevelt gave speeches to support women’s rights.

B.Choice: Amelia Earhart was the first woman to cross the Atlantic Ocean in an airplane.

C.Choice: Amelia Earhart was a determined female pilot who disappeared on a flight around the world.

D.Choice: Amelia Earhart became a career counselor at Purdue and advised women  students.

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What is the meaning of “always kind of kicked the idea around a little bit” in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: thought about the idea from time to time

B.Choice: wanted to be a professional soccer player

C.Choice: did not like making a decision

D.Choice: did not like the idea of cooking

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement from the text supports the idea that being a chef is more than just cooking?

A.Choice: “First of all, it takes a little bit of schooling.”

B.Choice: “With the Food Network and things like that, people are a little more aware of what’s going on and a little more educated about cooking.”

C.Choice: “A typical day is coming in, going over financial reports from the previous day, meeting with your staff and going over menu development.”

D.Choice: “It changes—every day it’s something different.”

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does “sous chef” mean in paragraph 13?

A.Choice: planner

B.Choice: manager

C.Choice: pastry chef

D.Choice: assistant chef

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Why is it important for a chef to have creativity?

A.Choice: The chef has to be willing to find enjoyment when working on the weekends and holidays.

B.Choice: The chef has to be able to change the menu for each group being served.

C.Choice: The chef has to be able to plan ahead to prepare for large groups of customers.

D.Choice: The chef has to be able to communicate directly with all those involved with preparing the food.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement from the text supports the idea that chefs have unusual hours?

A.Choice: “It’s a lot of planning.”

B.Choice: “Every day it’s something different.”

C.Choice: “When everybody is playing, you’re working.”

D.Choice: “We’re going to have a wide variety of things.”

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement from the text supports that chocolate is an important ingredient for Chef Justus?

A.Choice: “He comes up with recipes to go on the menus.”

B.Choice: “I like the dark chocolates.”

C.Choice: “We use the chocolates as much as we can.”

D.Choice: “We do a chocolate-barbecued chicken wing.”

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How does the author show that being an executive chef is hard work?

A.Choice: by showing the many different duties of an executive chef every day

B.Choice: by describing the many recipes that an executive chef can make each season

C.Choice: by explaining the different classes that an executive chef must complete

D.Choice: by talking about the people who have eaten in his restaurant recently

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: What is the main idea of this text?

A.Choice: Recipes have to be creative and fun.

B.Choice: Chefs do many things besides cooking.

C.Choice: Working different hours is part of being a chef.

D.Choice: Chocolate can be used in many different recipes.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement from the text shows that Trigger was a smart dog?

A.Choice: “Trigger was a railroad dog right from the start.”

B.Choice: “One of Charlie’s duties was to turn the switch, and Trigger went with him.”

C.Choice: “Hearing those engine whistles all the time, Trigger learned to tell them apart.”

D.Choice: “Trigger went with Charlie each time and stood beside him.”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including words that affect meaning and tone.
Content: What is the meaning of “fetch” in paragraph 11?

A.Choice: set up

B.Choice: run toward

C.Choice: give away

D.Choice: bring back

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: What does Charlie’s reaction to the frozen switch show about him?

A.Choice: He is worried.

B.Choice: He is surprised.

C.Choice: He is frustrated.

D.Choice: He is disappointed.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: How did the dog stop the train from crashing?

A.Choice: He barked at the train driver.

B.Choice: He moved the switch.

C.Choice: He ran to get the red flag.

D.Choice: He ran beside the train.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which quote from the text supports the theme of bravery?

A.Choice: “Trigger took such an interest in the switching that Charlie made a decision.”

B.Choice: “Charlie discovered a section of track that needed repair.”

C.Choice: “Trigger scampered along, his curly black ears flopping in the biting wind.”

D.Choice: “There was Trigger in the center of the track, sitting proudly on his hind legs.”

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: Why does the train almost fall off the mountain?

A.Choice: The switch is frozen.

B.Choice: The brakes stop working.

C.Choice: The driver is asleep.

D.Choice: The station agent is injured.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: How does Trigger learning how to stop a train contribute to the end of the text?

A.Choice: He learns how to turn the switch.

B.Choice: He is able to save many people’s lives.

C.Choice: He makes the people on the train angry.

D.Choice: He is unable to move the switch.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: Which statement summarizes the text?

A.Choice: A dog loves to ride a train.

B.Choice: A dog stops a train wreck.

C.Choice: A man adopts a dog.

D.Choice: A man hurts his knee.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: Why were scientists surprised to find dinosaur bones near Antarctica?

A.Choice: They believed dinosaurs could only have survived in warm climates.

B.Choice: They believed Australia and Antarctica would have had different temperatures.

C.Choice: They believed dinosaurs migrated away from cold climates.

D.Choice: They believed all dinosaurs became extinct because of cold weather.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How does the author tell about the climate of Dinosaur Cove?

A.Choice: by explaining how dinosaurs had to adapt

B.Choice: by comparing it to the weather of Alaska

C.Choice: by identifying differences between its location then and now

D.Choice: by describing the amount of daylight during different seasons

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: What does the word “plunged” mean in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: ran toward

B.Choice: pushed away

C.Choice: fell suddenly

D.Choice: walked slowly

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How does the author explain the effect of living at Dinosaur Cove on the dinosaurs?

A.Choice: by showing that dinosaur fossils were found there by paleontologists

B.Choice: by showing that dinosaurs of Dinosaur Cove lived on a peninsula and could not migrate

C.Choice: by describing that dinosaurs were like turtles, snakes, and crocodiles

D.Choice: by describing that dinosaurs of Dinosaur Cove were the last dinosaurs on Earth

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which statement from the text explains what helped dinosaurs stay alive in the darkness?

A.Choice: “In other parts of the world, dinosaurs probably migrated away from the winter’s darkness.”

B.Choice: “Since these trees didn’t lose their needles in the winter, they were food for the plant-eating dinosaurs.”

C.Choice: “Big eyes also helped the dinosaurs watch out for predators that would have hunted them.”

D.Choice: “If dinosaurs were ‘warm-blooded’ like birds, then they could have made their own heat.”

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: According to the text, why were the dinosaurs in Dinosaur Cove unable to move to a warmer place?

A.Choice: They lived on an island and could not travel.

B.Choice: It was too dangerous to migrate.

C.Choice: They did not know about warmer places.

D.Choice: Warmer places were too far away.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: How does the author show in paragraph 12 that scientists may not have all the information they need?

A.Choice: by asking a lot of questions

B.Choice: by talking about the extinction of dinosaurs

C.Choice: by telling the reader that information is hard to find

D.Choice: by using a timeline of events

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which detail supports the main idea?

A.Choice: that dinosaurs could see in the dark

B.Choice: that dinosaurs could not swim

C.Choice: that dinosaurs survived in cold places

D.Choice: that dinosaurs migrated to warmer places
